werewolf_recipe_decoded.title: The Werewolf Recipe Decoded
werewolf_recipe_decoded.grimoire_source: Iron cooking pot contains: Water, Parsley, Opium, Saffron. 'You do not eat it, it is to attack the devil.' Rub body with fat of freshly killed cat. Put on wolf's skin.
werewolf_recipe_decoded.key_insight: The 'unremarkable' parsley is THE KEY - it's the enzyme inhibitor that potentiates the opium absorbed through cat fat on the skin.

who_were_the_midwives.key_insight: The Midwives were very Important in the Ancient World... And then they were Later Labeled as 'Witches'. Leading up to Books like Daemonologie by King James.

king_james_daemonologie.key_change: Changed 'Thou must not suffer a poisoner to live' to 'Thou must not suffer a witch to live'
king_james_daemonologie.direct_target: charms as commonly daft wives use, for healing of forspoken goods, for preserving them from evil eyes, by knitting sundry kinds of herbs
king_james_daemonologie.note: Women known as healers and midwives often came under suspicion because of their skills

Later became marginalized as 'witches' after Christianization

Tales traced back thousands of years to oral traditions
Beauty and the Beast and Rumpelstiltskin traced to prehistoric Indo-European origins

romani_connection.framework: The Grim Brothers Fairy Tales come mostly from the Romani People and so from India and the East
evidence: Romani word páni (water) = Sanskrit hasta, Hindustani hāth
Same tales found: Poland, Wales, India, Norway, Sicily
Connection between the Gypsy and the Indian folk-tale seems scarcely less obvious than that between páni, water, in Rómani, and páni, water, in Hindustani
